facts.text: Jaswant Singh employed as Patwari, Fatehpur Rajputan.

Appellant prosecuted for habitually accepting illegal gratification; specific charge: received Rs. 50 on 19-3-1953 at Subzi Mandi Amritsar from Pal Singh as reward for forwarding application Es. A. with recommendation for allotment of Ahata No. 10 to Santa Singh father of Pal Singh.

Special Judge, Amritsar, in Corruption Case No. 13/1-10/3 of 1953, judgment dated 14-9-1953: found appellant accepted illegal gratification from Pal Singh, Hazara Singh, Harnam Singh, Joginder Singh, Atma Singh, Hari Singh and Ganda Singh; specifically Rs. 50 from Pal Singh on 19-3-1953; held charge under s.5(1)(a) established, guilty under s.5(2).

Punjab High Court, Criminal Appeal No. 540 of 1953, judgment dated 31-12-1953 by Dulat J.: sanction valid only qua Rs. 50 from Pal Singh; conviction upheld for that but not for habitual; sentence reduced to period undergone, fine maintained.

Sanction by N.N. Kashyap, ICS, Deputy Commissioner, Amritsar under s.6: for Rs. 50 in 5 notes of Rs.10 from Pal Singh son of Santa Singh for favourable report on allotment application to Santa Singh; satisfied offence under s.5.

legal_issues.text: Validity and effect of sanction under s.6 of Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947; whether sanction confined to single instance of Rs.50 from Pal Singh renders trial for habitual acceptance under s.5(1)(a) without jurisdiction, and voids conviction even for single act.
Whether evidence of habitual bribery caused prejudice to defence on single instance charge.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sanction confined to illegal gratification of Rs.50 from Pal Singh (offence under s.5(1)(d)); charge and trial for habitually accepting under s.5(1)(a); trial wholly void without jurisdiction; cannot convict even for offence in sanction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act; Basudeo Agarwala v. King Emperor

petitioner_arguments.text: Evidence of habitual receiving caused serious prejudice to defence.

court_reasoning.text: Sanction must refer to facts constituting offence; strictly construed, valid only for receiving Rs.50 from Pal Singh (s.5(1)(d)); not for habitual under s.5(1)(a).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sanctioning authority considered evidence for single act only.

court_reasoning.text: Lack of sanction for habitual offence bars cognizance of that offence, making prosecution/trial void for it; but does not bar cognizance/trial for single act which had valid sanction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.6(1) bars jurisdiction only for unsanctioned offence; distinct offences separable.

court_reasoning.text: No prejudice shown from habitual evidence; High Court finding on Pal Singh transaction well-founded; no argument on correctness of that finding.

holdings.text: Trial for habitual offence under s.5(1)(a) void for want of sanction; trial/conviction for single offence of receiving Rs.50 under s.5(1)(d) valid.

precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction provisions observed with complete strictness; not automatic formality.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction in respect of facts constituting offence; facts should be referred on face or proved by evidence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Yusofalli Mulla Noorbhoy v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Valid sanction essential for jurisdiction; without it, prosecution nullity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown
precedents_cited.relevance: Lack of sanction for one offence does not bar trial for another not requiring sanction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Basir-ul-Huq v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction requirement not bar to distinct offence not requiring it.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines criminal misconduct (habitual acceptance s.5(1)(a), single pecuniary advantage s.5(1)(d)); requires previous sanction for cognizance.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences requiring sanction under s.6 of Act; examples of distinct offences.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogy: not bar to distinct offence not requiring sanction.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior sanction requirement in Hori Ram case.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Punjab High Court: conviction for receiving Rs.50 illegal gratification from Pal Singh under s.5 upheld; habitual charge set aside for lack of sanction; no prejudice; agrees with High Court findings.
outcome.relief_granted: None; sentence as per High Court (period undergone + fine).

key_quotes.text: The sanction under the Act is not intended to be nor is an automatic formality and it is essential that the provisions in regard to sanction should be observed with complete strictness.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Section 6(1) of the Act bars the jurisdiction of the court to take cognizance of an offence for which previous sanction is required and has not been given.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on effect of invalid sanction.
